learning_outcomes.description: Identify a valid research topic and devise strategies for addressing it;

Conduct independent research into the chosen topic, utilising the various resources within the University Library system, and elsewhere, as necessary.  This would naturally include relevant databases, periodicals literature, collected editions, and/or a variety of other possible materials and resources;

Identify relevant information (fact, ideas, findings, etc.) in the exisiting literature and research around your topic by means of which it might be informed; structure these findings into an argument leading to valid research questions or hypotheses;
Identify and put into effect a suitable research method (or methods), within the methodological framework most applicable to the topic, in order to support your analysis or critique and findings;

Present the results of your research at a high standard, demonstrating strong command of written communication in academic English and professional-level standards in any creative work outputs (performance or composition folio);
Maintain a high standard of self critique in terms of the quality/originally of your ideas; quality and accuracy of your written expression; standards of your scholarly practice;

Demonstrate a conscientious approach to all aspects of scholarly practice, including fairness and transparency, referencing and citation, intellectual honesty, discipline-specific conduct and practices;
Observe proper ethical procedures for any aspects of the research that involve the participation of human subjects.

assessments.due_date:
6/03/2026 5:00 pm

This assessment item may be submitted any time prior to the due date.
assessments.task_description:
Your project plan is to focus your thinking about your research project early in the semester.

Your project plan should be prepared in consultation with your supervisor prior to submission and must be approved by the course co-ordinator (who may consult with your supervisor) prior to working further on your project. Once approved you may continue with your project. You may submit your project plan early if you and your advisor agree is it ready and notify the course co-ordinator so that they can expedite assessment. Your project plan may include relevant material from the research proposal submitted in the previous semester as part of your application to the course.

There is no set length to your plan, it should be long enough to provide a clear outline of how you propose to carry out your research.

Your project plan should consider the following:

  1. Your research question or hypothesis, or your vision for creative work
  2. Explain how your project relates to extending existing knowledge in the field
  3. Provide appropriate scoping out of the project, identifying suitable methods, research strategies, resources needed, and so on
  4. Set out the timeline of activities, including research and drafting milestones, and milestones for creative work where applicable
  5. If needed, provide evidence of ethics approval or application in progress
assessments.submission_guidelines: Use provided form and submit via the provided link in the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Evidence of Human Research Ethics Approval
assessments.due_date:
23/03/2026 5:00 pm

NB: Note that the due date refers to having a completed and approved application, or an application that is likely to be approved with modifications according to the feedback received by the relevant ethics board. It does NOT refer to the date by which the initial submission is to be made.

If ethics clearance is not given, you will need to reconsider the nature of your project or withdrawal from the course. (Census date is Monday, 31 March 2025, a week after the Ethics Approval due date). Please work proactively with your supervisor and allow plenty of time.
assessments.task_description:
For projects that require ANY research involving human subjects or human-related materials, it is necessary to obtain the appropriate ethics approvals to conduct this research before you commence data collection. 


Research involving human subjects or human-related materials that is not accompanied by the proper approvals cannot be accepted for assessment in this course. Moreover, the collection of data from human subjects or using human-materials without such approval is regarded as a form of research misconduct under the University's Policies & Procedures (see: https://policies.uq.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=346&version=2).


The latest date that evidence of approval should be provided is one week before the Semester One census date. If you do not have ethics approval by this date, you must either:

  • modify your research project such that it can be completed without reliance on research involving human subjects or human-related materials, or
  • drop the course.


Please be aware that dropping the course after the census date means you are financially liable for fees for this course.

For more information on obtaining ethics approval for conducting human-related research, see: https://music.uq.edu.au/student-support/research-ethics-approval-honours-and-coursework-masters.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Ethics applications need to be submitted by the student's supervisor, who is regarded as the lead investigator.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
A brief report is required from both students and supervisors at the end of the first semester of enrolment. This should address the following:

  • Objectives met as per the original plan submitted at the start of the course
  • Work remaining and updated timeline for completion of tasks
  • Changes that have arisen
  • Problems, if any, that have been encountered
  • Unforeseen resourcing requirements
  • A statement from the supervisor(s) is also required
assessments.submission_guidelines: Use provided form and submit via the provided link in the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.mode: Activity/ Performance, Product/ Artefact/ Multimedia, Written
assessments.task_description:
The thesis is c. 16,000 words in length. For creative practice research projects, the exegesis will be c. 8,000 words and the creative output should be commensurate to around 50% of the work. The balance between creative output and e3xegesis can be adjusted in consultation with your supervisor and with approval by the course co-ordinator.

Your project will be agreed upon primarily between you and your advisor, although the advice of the course co-ordinator may also be sought in this matter. You are strongly urged to consider your advisor's advice carefully (and that of the course co-ordinator, if applicable) in relation forming your project. Your results are much less likely to be satisfactory in cases where the you and your advisor do not agree on the feasibility of your project.


For matters relating to presentation of the final work, the you should:

  • follow the advice of your advisor;
  • consult the School of Music Academic Writing Guide
  • review previous theses and relevant outputs that are recommended by your advisor or course co-ordinator as exemplary.


Please note that the deadline for submitting a complete draft of your thesis to your advisor for final review is the Friday of Week 10 of the second semester. Advisors cannot guarantee to have time to read your final draft with sufficient attention after this time as well as have it returned to you with sufficient time for you to take meaningful action on suggestions. (Of course, it is expected that you will have been submitting material throughout the year regularly). Advisors are not obliged to read and respond to first drafts of lengthy written material after this time.


Format

For written components (thesis, exegesis) students should download the template that is provided to students in the MUSSC7000 Blackboard site and follow relevant guidelines in the School of Music Academic Writing Guide .


Submission

Submission of the written work is through Turnitin (via Blackboard).

Submission of the creative work might be through a scheduled live performance, and/or provision of suitable audio-visual artefacts submitted via the course Blackboard site.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You are required to upload an electronic copy (PDF) of your thesis to TurnItIn on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
9/11/2026 - 20/11/2026

Oral defence sessions will be scheduled at mutually agreeable times to staff and students involved.
assessments.task_description:
Following submission and assessment of the these, you are required to discuss your work with either the course co-ordinator, examiner or both. You can expect to be asked questions about certain aspects of your thesis and will have an opportunity to respond to assessment feedback.

A key part of the oral defence is to satisfy the course co-ordinator and/or examiner that your work meets expectations in relation to academic integrity. You need to be prepared to answer questions that evidence your clear and deep understanding of the work presented in the thesis or exegesis.
assessments.submission_guidelines: There is no submissable material, students simply come to the session as scheduled. Sessions will take a maximum of 20 minutes, but may be shorter.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Supervision

One-to-one supervision. This will be an ongoing arrangement between yourself and your supervisor. You and your supervisor arrange mutually suitable times for regular meetings in order to guide you in the development of your research, provide feedback on drafts, and so on.
